title: Rudy Rintala
text:
Rudolph Alexander "Rudy" Rintala (February 6, 1909 - December 11, 1999) was an American collegiate athlete from 1928 to 1932 who starred in <a href="American%20football">football</a>, <a href="baseball">baseball</a>, <a href="basketball">basketball</a>, and <a href="track%20and%20field">track and field</a> at <a href="Stanford%20University">Stanford University</a>. Regarded as an all-time great of the school's athletic program, Rintala was a participant in the <a href="American%20football%20at%20the%201932%20Summer%20Olympics">demonstration game of football</a> at the <a href="1932%20Summer%20Olympics">1932 Summer Olympics</a>, held in <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="California">California</a>. Rintala is a member of the Stanford University athletic hall of fame.
Biography.
Early years.
Rudolph Alexander "Rudy" Rintala was born on February 6, 1909, in <a href="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a>, <a href="New%20York%20City">New York</a>. He grew up in <a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a>, California, where he graduated from <a href="San%20Francisco%20Polytechnic%20High%20School">San Francisco Polytechnic High School</a>.
Sports career.
Rintala gained a reputation as an outstanding high school football player in the fall of 1927, playing <a href="halfback%20%28American%20football%29">halfback</a> on offense and showing skill as a tackler on the defensive side of the ball.
Rintala attended <a href="Stanford%20University">Stanford University</a>, where he first played for the school's Freshman team in the fall of 1928. The next year he moved to the varsity team, playing left halfback for legendary coach <a href="Pop%20Warner">Glenn S. "Pop" Warner</a>. Rintala was small and agile, standing 5'9" tall and weighing 170 pounds in 1929, his Sophomore year.
Rintala also starred as a <a href="outfielder">center fielder</a> for the Stanford baseball team, batting cleanup and serving as team captain in 1932. He also was a starting <a href="guard%20%28basketball%29">guard</a> for the Stanford basketball team, and threw <a href="javelin">javelin</a> for the school's varsity track and field squad.
Rintala was the 1932 recipient of the Jake Gimbel Award, an annual prize presented to an outstanding senior athlete "whose attitude toward things athletic is outstanding."
Rintala graduated from Stanford in 1932 with a degree in <a href="accounting">accounting</a>. Following graduation, he continued to play football for a time for the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Olympic%20Club">San Francisco Olympic Club</a>, competing alongside other former collegiate stars against other amateur clubs and college teams.
In the middle of July 1932, Rintala reported for his first practice with one of two all-star squads selected to play a demonstration game of football at the <a href="1932%20Summer%20Olympics">1932 Summer Olympics</a> in Los Angeles. This game, which pitted recently graduated students from three East Coast football powers (<a href="Harvard%20College">Harvard</a>, <a href="Yale%20College">Yale</a>, and <a href="Princeton%20University">Princeton</a>) against those from three top West Coast schools — the <a href="University%20of%20Southern%20California">University of Southern California</a>, Stanford, and the <a href="University%20of%20California%2C%20Berkeley">University of California, Berkeley</a>. On the night of August 8, 1932, some 60,000 fans attended the contest at the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Coliseum">Los Angeles Coliseum</a>, seeing a hard-fought battle which was won late in the game by the West, 7-6.
Life after athletics.
In 1933, Rintala married the former Mary Thayer. The couple raised two children, a son and a daughter.
He subsequently worked as an accountant for many years in the steel industry before going into private practice as a <a href="certified%20public%20accountant">certified public accountant</a> in 1956. He retired from the profession in 1974.
Death and legacy.
Rudy Rintala died December 11, 1999, at his home in <a href="Atherton%2C%20California">Atherton, California</a>. He was 90 years old at the time of his death.
Rintala was elected to the <a href="Stanford%20Sports%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Stanford Sports Hall of Fame</a> in September 1964 for his baseball career. As a four-sport collegiate star, he is regarded as an icon of athletic prowess by in the lore of Stanford athletics, with a name mentioned alongside the school's All-American multi-sport legend, <a href="Ernie%20Nevers">Ernie Nevers</a>.
